text: English writing skills punctuation marks
lesson 5 in this lesson we'll review how
we rate dates with dashes slashes and
apostrophes and which formats are
standard in American English we'll also
review how we write the time of day with
a colon and we'll talk about writing
numbers when do we use words when do we
use numerals
hello everyone this is lesson 5 do you
know when I posted the first lesson of
this series I posted it on Sunday April
28th 2013 how would I write that date in
this sentence do you know what standard
in American English
Jennifer posted the first lesson of this
series on we'll start with the day of
the week Sunday , the month April the
day 28
we need another comma and then the year
2013 some people ask do you need to
write the th for 28 no those little
letters and ordinal numbers like the Rd
and 23rd or the st and 21st do not need
to be written in the date in this format
it's not necessary we understand how to
read the date we read with ordinal
numbers but it's not necessary to write
those little letters it could be written
however those little letters could be
written if we reverse the number and the
month for example on the 28th of April
this is not as common I think it's more
typical of more formal English in
everyday writing why use more words if
you don't have to in fact to be even
quicker we would simply use numerals
when we write so leaving out sunday we
could say April 28 2013 and in the
United States we like dashes or do you
know dashes or slashes
yeah periods are gaining some use but
it's still not what I would consider a
standard pattern so when you write a
date with numerals only stick to slashes
or dashes and remember the pattern in
the US is to use the month day and then
the year let's add the time of day I
remember that the first video was posted
exactly at 11:04 a.m. how do I write
that 11 : Beaufort a.m. of course we
read o 4 but we know that is a number
not a letter a M stands for the morning
hours PM refers to afternoon and evening
hours remember that in the US we don't
usually have that 24-hour clock we use
am & PM a.m. can be written with
lowercase letters and periods or
uppercase letters and no periods the
same pattern holds true for p.m. let's
say that the video had been posted
exactly at 11 o'clock would I need to
write 0 0 no it's not really necessary
if it had been posted exactly at 11
o'clock right on the hour I could just
write 11 a.m. okay would you ever need
to write out 11 as a word perhaps in a
more formal situation and you were using
o clock then it would be more standard
more appropriate to write 11 as a word o
clock 11 o'clock
hopefully you're making use of the
exercises on my website they give
additional practice with all of these
punctuation patterns some of the
exercises refer to TV shows made in the
1960s and 70s how would I write those
decades in this sentence do you know
there are a couple different patterns
let's use this one first let's use
numbers in the 1960s does that look good
am I missing anything no I don't need an
apostrophe here just 1960 and then at s
1960s and 70s does that look okay well
here I left out the 19 so I will use an
apostrophe to show that I left out the
first two numbers the 1960s and 70s okay
this is the pattern for a reference to
any decade the 1960s the 1970s the 60s
the 70s the 80s by the way I love the
80s but that's probably showing my age
because some of you were probably not
even born in the 80s but a lot of music
that I listen to happens to be from that
decade okay could we use words yes
okay if we say 60s and 70s
it's like this shorthand this
abbreviation for the 70s it would assume
that everyone understands which decade
or which century were referring to they
didn't have TV shows in the 1800s
so of course we're talking about the
1970s the 1960s so you could write out
the words you could use numbers you only
need the apostrophe if you leave out the
first two numbers okay this is the end
of part one please go on to the next
